185106858.review:
Starting with the biggest issue: The game does not respect your sensitivity to bright/flashing lights/epilepsy. If you die on the ground your screen flashes white. In combat people have "powers" that make your screen flash white. This is unacceptable. 

Likes: 
-The synergy between ship and crew results in spectacle. That's the essence of Trek.
-It's the good kind of free to play where everything you buy enhances your experience.
-They constantly give you ships and upgrades through events. You don't need to spend money, just play through a holiday.
-Generally nice community of Trekkies 

Dislikes:
-The onboarding process is garbage. It takes a week to go to level 30 where the game unlocks enough that you can try everything. You can't just tell a friend to join you because they'll have a bad time.
-The 15m EC cap is the scummiest and stingiest thing in the game. 
-Bridges are functionally useless and that's a big missed opportunity.
-The storyline has been written, rewritten, truncated, spliced, diced and minced over the years. 
-The game will likely never see any upgrades to it's engine or mechanics.
-Experienced players will rush through co-op missions leaving you scratching your head as to what to do.

184862968.review:
I personally like how grindy this game is, and enjoy playing it for that purpose.
Meets my expectations of what's Trekky enough, and personally enjoy the style and everything.
The story's enjoyable and branches off as its own universe instead of connecting with the prime timeline from the shows.
It runs well on old hardware, just would be nice to get a graphics overhaul for the game some day, perhaps accessible with higher-level settings, like realism-off, realism-low, realism-medium and realism-high. The game really needs better lighting and textures.

I haven't gotten myself into the spending frenzy, and haven't spent a single dime on the game.
It's possible to obtain pretty much all premium items through the events and/or grinding. There's also Epic Games who give away free premium items every once in a while.

Now yes, the events do get stale after a while. Just take a break, and when you feel like playing this game once more, just hop on and play. It'll feel a bit more enjoyable instead of stale.

If you're not a grindy person and get into spending money on games easily, this game is not for you.

I have [b]over 500 hours[/b] outside of the Steam client, so yes, I've been playing this game for quite some time and am more than qualified enough to talk about it like this.

184540480.review:
Whether you like MMOs or not, the solo experience in this game is very satisfying with many great missions and excellently realised ships. It's a reasonably generous free to play model. You won't be able to get everything and certainly not everything the day it's released, but if you're patient you can earn plenty of free ships just by playing the game. The endgame is fine. If you play content that is currently tied to an event the queues are super short, but if you want to play something more off the beaten track you will need to find a fleet of likeminded players. Fleets are very mature content now so it's easy to find one with all of the perks and no demand for anything from the player except that they engage with the other fleet members. All-in-all there's a lot here for the casual Star Trek fan for no upfront cost and with some patience you can get some of the very best ships in the game for no money. 

A strong recommend for a Star Trek fan. A weaker recommend if you're susceptible to lootbox mechanics. They're easily ignored, but beware nonetheless.

184508640.review: If you are a fan of Star Trek, then this game is worth trying. Make sure to set the resolution sliders to max, and it can look pretty good, even today. The missions are fun, and the community is helpful.

184480230.review: For a free-to--play MMO focused in the Star Trek IP, this is a great game, given its age. There are three levels of the game, FPS, ship combat, and galactic travel. to put that in a game from 2011 is impressive. Nothing spectacular, and the game has probably been on life support for the last 5 years, but the RP community keeps it engaging, and if you want to RP in a Star Trek world, this would be a great place to do it.

184269907.review:
I have played this game since the early beta days, then ended up dropping it for a couple years, then they went free to play, 700 day veteran, all that stuff along with every event the last 8 or so years.

Is STO a good game?  No.

It is a functional game, with minimal crash issues, with minimal technical issues, they have kept it fresh mostly over the years, but given the pay to win and lootbox situation it has taken me a decade just to get ships I wanted, equipment I wanted, get characters I wanted to use.

And yet I still recommend it to Trek fans simply because of people like Thomas Marrone who pour their heart and soul into designs of ships, the efforts of new people on the team constantly working to improve the experience for players who have stuck with this game for so long.

I like STO, I am glad it is my go to MMO, I am glad to have met the people I have met in the greater Trek community because of it, and I hope as they move forward they continue to improve and finish the product and tie it into new media.

Beyond that, controller support on PC is trash and garbage, deck support requires plugging in keyboards or mashing on the touch screen constantly.

Come on Cyrptic and Arc games, it is time you port the console controller support to PC.

184186713.review: I will recommend the game. However, there are many mission bugs such as NPC's failing to spawn and missions not completing as a result. If you enjoy the Star Trek universe this is still a great game, but there are still some serious mission bugs that show their heads every now and then that make it hard to complete a mission.

184114450.review: If you're into Star Trek and MMOs in general this is a great game. It takes place after the events of Nemesis and 2009 Reboot, but continuing the narrative in the "Prime" timeline. Borg, Klingons, Romulans, Jem'Hadar, Delta Quadrant unfinished business, as will as Mirror Universe and species 8472 incursions. This game tries to hit every Star Trek aspect on the head, and does it well.

184097801.review: i hate borg, they are the absolute worst

184088617.review:
[h1][i]“It's been a long road~”[/i] 🎵
~Diane Warren, Russell Watson[/h1]

Reviewing MMOs is a bad idea. Those games change so much on the way that reading the old reviews feels a lot like reading about entirely different game. Yet in this case? I think I'll make an exception. See, at this point the game doesn't change that much anymore. Publisher moved it to another developer, the one that is known to keep old MMOs alive, while instead of expansions, we've got new story episodes dropping now and then. Guess, it's a good time to look back at [b]STO[/b]. Lots of you, people, dislike [b]Enterprise[/b] opening, but let's just admit it – it's been a long road.

It all started almost 15 years ago, in 2010. It was about a year before [b]Star Wars: The Old Republic[/b], [b]The Lord of the Rings Online[/b] just went f2p... And here it was. A long-awaited game based on one of the most influential Sci-Fi shows in history. And you know what? It was pretty cool. [b]Cryptic[/b], creators of games like [b]City of Heroes[/b] and [b]Champions Online[/b], sure knew how to think outside the box. What did we get? Well, a lot of stuff, actually. The players were divided between two factions – [b]United Federation of Planets[/b] and [b]Klingon Defense Force[/b] (still are, while non-human and non-[b]Klingon[/b] chars simply join as allies), while gameplay revolves around two things – [b]WoW[/b]-like instances on ground and space combat.

In other words, we've got not one, but two games. The ground operations are our usual MMO stuff. Grab the gun, equip some skills and then kill things. The usual. Far from being bad, since some of such operations are pretty creative (a bit too creative at times if you know what I mean), but still, nothing special. Heck, some people prefer not to play ground missions at all and stick with... Yeah. You guessed it. The main dish. Space. [i]The final frontier.[/i]

The space battles in [b]STO[/b] is, exactly as it should be, a ship porn. There's a vast selection of ships in this game, both those from original media (shows, movies, books...), and exclusive to the game. And while usually, I'm not a fan of made up stuff, this time? I must say, those ships are great. So great there are actually collectible models with those. And I do have lots of them. Now think about it. Picking up your favorite [b]Star Trek[/b] ship, hiring a crew and then doing something I can somewhat compare to, say, [b]World of Tanks[/b] with 'em? Sounds like a dream, right? Well, in a way it is. [i]But[/i]. Only after a year on market, [b]STO[/b] followed [b]LoTRO[/b] into the f2p territory. And, as you can easily guess, all the best ships are sold separately now. Wait, wait, wait! Don't close this page yet, keep reading.

See, unlike most of the other f2p games, [b]STO[/b] actually has pretty nice f2p model. You [i]do[/i] earn premium currency with time (even more if you have more than one toon) and there's a never-ending cycle of giveaways and events that'll reward you with top tier ships. Which won't be as good as those that you'll pay for, of course, but still, those are pretty solid. In other words, the game is 100% playable for free. If you'll want to become top player, you'll still want to pay, say, the price of a [b]Final Fantasy XIV[/b], but that's it. That'll be enough for you to do PVP and stuff. And after that? After that you won't need to invest anything. One of the reasons I like this game. I mean, usually, f2p games are very hard on your wallet, while those that require subscription make me feel bad about literally burning money while not playing. This here? Is totally my kind of stuff. In a way, it feels a lot like “buy to play”. You buy some stuff to make one of them top builds and then forget about paying completely.

It's not that simple, though. The thing is, in its current form, [b]STO[/b] heavily revolves around dailies. So-called endeavors are a very long series of daily tasks that provide major bonuses to your stats account-wide. Nothing complicated, just kill some enemies here and do certain “instances” (called TFO) there. Usually takes about 30 minutes per day, but it means you'll need to be there. Every. Bloody. Day. Those events I've mentioned are like that too. Just be there. Otherwise even paying the real money won't help. I mean, what's the point paying for a good ship with the best hardware if you miss things like +50% damage from endeavors? And to complete your endeavors? You'll need to play for, like, a couple of years. Again, you won't need to invest lot of time. [b]STO[/b] is not one of those games that can ruin your personal life. But still, it's one of those games that you visit. Every day.

Even if you won't want to be a top player, though, [b]STO[/b] is a lot of fun. Why? Well, because of its story. It's smart (love it what they did with the [b]V'ger[/b] from the first movie), there's a lot of lore involved from all the shows, and the best of all? The story is voiced by real actors.  Lots and lots of our favorites are there – from [b]Leonard Nimoy[/b] ([b]Mr. Spock[/b]) to [b]Sonequa Martin-Green[/b] ([b]Michael Burnham[/b]). Even the passed actors are presented in a form of archive sound, while [b]Scotty[/b] is voiced by [b]James Doohan[/b]'s son, [b]Christopher[/b]. Same [b]Christopher[/b], who played [b]Scotty[/b] in that awesome fan series [b]Star Trek Continues[/b]. The other guys from [b]STC[/b] are here too, while story also brings back characters nobody expected to see again. Like, we all loved [b]Jadzia[/b] from [b]DS9[/b], but there was also something very special about [b]Ezri[/b], who showed us just how hard things can be for joined [b]Trill[/b]. It was a shame that she only had one season. Good news! [b]Nicole de Boer[/b] and her character is in [b]STO[/b] too. You like [b]Trek[/b]? You should totally play through story at least once. And you know what? It's free for everybody. No need to pay for the new episodes, no need to be a top player to clear the whole thing.

Sounds like a perfect MMO, right? Well... Not really. If something, [b]STO[/b] is far from perfection. It can be clunky, it's managed by ridiculously small team, which, instead of fixing ages old bugs, keep bringing the new ones in updates, cosmetics are half-broken and very hard to manage, while, the worst of all, there's no open world areas. Well, technically, those exist, but they just... don't feel right. Galaxy map is empty and useless ([b]Cryptic[/b] tried to fix that by adding encounters and mini operations called “patrols” for different systems, but all in all, it didn't help and exploring just isn't a thing), while so-called battlezones are painfully repetitive and, most likely, you'll only be doing those for endeavors. And it's a [i]huge[/i] problem. Summer / winter festivals, where lots of people gather on special locations show exactly how much fun this game can be with proper open world environment, but no. It is not a thing.

[b]STO[/b] is just that. A game you visit every day for 30-60 minutes, clear endeavors, do a couple of favorite TFOs and then quit because there's nothing else to do (if you finished story that is). That's probably why the majority of players here are old alcoholics who keep whining about how bad the “new [b]Trek[/b]” is. Don't get me wrong, the audience here is far from being toxic as in, say, [b]WoW[/b], but still, “I'm so drunk”, “[b]Discovery[/b] is the worst!” and “Let's talk politics” is what zone chat is all about. You have been warned. In other words, you want MMO experience with a huge world and lots of things to do? This here is not it. Technically, there's [i]a lot[/i] of things here, but at this point most of those don't matter (even transwarp feature can be ignored by simply utilizing new “jump to an episode” option). And in a way? It's a good thing. With a fair monetization policy and with no need to invest too much time? [b]STO[/b] is, like, perfect addition to your [b]Star Trek[/b] experience. Dixi.

184075342.review: Great standard MMo experience plus star trek its great if you love those 2 things.

184031991.review: I have played STO for a long time off and on I would take breaks and took a rather long one but every time I come back its got a lot to do. The stories are good.

183887252.review:
I wish there was kind of a middle of the road rating for this.
I've come and gone from this game ever since it first released.
Everything about it is kind of middle of the road for me. At times it's fun and exciting to play and then at other times horribly boring. 

It's definitely a game that can be heavily dependent on grinding. Build your ship or your character specs wrong and you'll have a horrible time. Building things to perfection and you can dominate. There's DEFINITELY a TON of cash grabs going on in the game from cosmetics to pay-to-win type upgrades and some aspects of the game are heavily dependent on group play to grant you access to features. I don't generally experience this as I was one of the original players with a lifetime subscription so when they went free to play this was changed to grant players like me a monthly stipend. So when I do go back to playing I'm generally stupid rich across the board.

I just wish someone would come around with a hybrid Star Trek Bridge Commander and Star Trek Elite force.
